answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Bill,
I have been able to locate a few documents that will hopefully answer your question. 
First, in this document by John McGillicuddy, he describes where their organization has decided to place GIS departmentally.  On the third and fourth page of the document, it is established that placing GIS in a specific department was not beneficial and that independent work teams are more effective:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/20328/GIS__CRM_in_Mecklenburg_County_NC
Gary Palmer and Robbi McKinney also outline on page ten of their Strategic Plan the way they have allocated their 2010-2011 budget in regards to overall GIS costs:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301925/Local_Govt_GIS_Strategic_Planning
Additionally, the entire document is a good example of a strategic plan created specifically for GIS use. Pages six to ten may prove useful by outlining issues, goals, and objectives, along with performance measures and desired outcomes.
There is also a presentation on the GIS system as used in Des Moines, Iowa. The presentation generally focuses on management challenges and solutions, but slides six and nine provide good data as to how their resources are divided up: 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2370/Building_and_Using_GIS_in_the_City_of_Des_Moines_Iowa 
I also recommend getting in contact with the topic leaders listed on the GIS topic page if you have any additional questions or want further clarification.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/113/GIS
I hope this helps!
Amanda Dodge
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org
